member.name: T:KBCsv.CsvReader
member.summary: Provides a means of reading CSV data.

remarks.para: The CsvReader class allows CSV data to be read from an underlying data source. The data source may be a , , file, or just a containing CSV data. There are various constructors allowing for file-, Stream- and TextWriter- based data sources, whilst facilitates reading CSV data from a .
By default, CSV values are assumed to be separated with a comma (,) and optionally delimited with double quotes ("). If necessary, the and properties enable these default to be customized.
Leading and trailing white space is discarded by default. and can be used to override these defaults.

A header record can be read, either by calling (or ) or by assigning one directly to the property. The latter approach is particularly useful when the underlying data does not actually contain the header record, but the structure of the data is known. Any attempts to read or assign a header record after the first record has been read by a CsvReader will result in an exception.

Data can be skipped via or (or their async counterparts, and ). Skipping data is faster than reading (and discarding) it. Thus, if it is known that a number of records are not needed, it is recommended they be skipped rather than read.
The property gives the total number of records read, including any header record.

member.threadsafety: A CsvReader cannot be used safely from multiple threads without synchronization. When using the Async methods, you should ensure that any prior task has completed before instigating another.

example.para: The following example uses to parse data in a . Values in data records are accessed via an index:
The following example uses to parse data in a . White space is preserved:
The following example reads data from a file, where values are tab-separated and delimited with single quotes:
The following example reads data from an underlying UTF-8 encoded . It treats the first record as a , thus enabling the data to be accessed via column names.
The following example reads data from a file. It explicitly assigns a and skips every other record:

The following example reads data asynchronously from an underlying . It uses instead of to avoid creating too fine-grained tasks. It also requests that the be left open when disposing the CsvReader. All data records are dumped to the console:

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvReader.PreserveLeadingWhiteSpace
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether leading white space should be preserved.

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvReader.PreserveTrailingWhiteSpace
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether trailing white space should be preserved.

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvReader.ValueSeparator
member.summary: Gets or sets the character used to separate values within the CSV.
member.remarks: This property specifies what character is used to separate values within the CSV. The default value separator is a comma (,).

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvReader.ValueDelimiter
member.summary: Gets or sets the character used to delimit values within the CSV.

remarks.para: This property specifies what character is used to delimit values within the CSV. The default value delimiter is a double quote ("). If set to , no character will be treated as a delimiter.

Note that values within the CSV are not required to be delimited. However, delimiting a value allows it to contain the delimiter character itself, along with new line characters (ie. a multi-line value).

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvReader.HeaderRecord
member.summary: Gets or sets the header record.

remarks.para: This property will be automatically set if or is called. Alternatively, it can be set explicitly in the case where the underlying data source does not itself contain a header record, but the structure of the data is known.
Any produced by this CsvReader will have its property set to the value of this property. Setting a header record allows the values within data records to be accessed both by index and by column name.
Any attempt to set this property when the first record has already been read will result in an exception.

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvReader.RecordNumber
member.summary: Gets the current record number.
member.remarks: This property gives the number of records that have been read by this CsvReader. This includes the header record, unless it is provided explicitly via the property.

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvReader.HasMoreRecords
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether there are more records to read.

member.name: M:KBCsv.CsvReader.FromCsvString(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a CsvReader that will read the CSV data in .
member.param: The CSV data to read.
member.returns: A CsvReader that will read the CSV in .

member.summary: Attempts to skip a record in the data, and increments if successful.
member.returns: if the record is successfully skipped, or if there are no more records to skip.

member.summary: Attempts to skip a record in the data, optionally incrementing if successful.

member.returns: if the record is successfully skipped, or if there are no more records to skip.

member.remarks: If there are fewer than records remaining in the data, this method will skip the remaining records and return the number of records actually skipped.
member.param: The number of records to skip.
member.returns: The actual number of records skipped.

to increment by the number of records skipped.

remarks.para: If successful, all s read by this CsvReader will have their set accordingly.
Any attempt to call this method when this CsvReader has already read a record will result in an exception.

member.returns: The that was read, also available via the property. If no records are left, this method returns .

member.name: T:KBCsv.CsvWriter
member.summary: Provides a means of writing CSV data.

remarks.para: The CsvWriter class allows CSV data to be written to an underlying data sink. The data sink may be a , , or a file. There are various constructors allowing for file-, Stream- and TextWriter- based data sinks.

By default, CSV values will be separated with a comma (,) and delimited where necessary with double quotes ("). If desired, the and properties enable these defaults to be customized. In addition, delimiters around values can be included even when not necessary by setting the property to .
Records can be written with and methods (or their async counterparts, and ). Doing so will increase accordingly.

member.threadsafety: A CsvReader cannot be used safely from multiple threads without synchronization. When using the Async methods, you should ensure that any prior task has completed before instigating another.

example.para: The following example writes CSV data to a :
The following example writes CSV data (with delimiters forced) to a with ASCII encoding. The is left open when the CsvWriter is closed:

The following example asynchronously reads CSV from a file and asynchronously writes it to another. The data is written as tab-delimited with a single quote delimiter. A buffer is used to read and write data in blocks of records rather than one record at a time:

member.param: A stream to which CSV data will be written.

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvWriter.Encoding
member.summary: Gets the being used when writing CSV data.

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvWriter.RecordNumber
member.summary: Gets the current record number.
member.remarks: This property gives the number of records that have been written by this CsvWriter.

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvWriter.ForceDelimit
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether delimiters should always be written.

remarks.para: If this property is set to , values will always be wrapped in s, even if they're not actually required. If , values will only be delimited where necessary. That is, when they contain characters that require delimiting.
Note that you cannot set this property to if has been set to .

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvWriter.ValueSeparator
member.summary: Gets or sets the character used to separate values within the CSV.
member.remarks: This property specifies what character is used to separate values within the CSV. The default value separator is a comma (,).

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvWriter.ValueDelimiter
member.summary: Gets or sets the character used to delimit values within the CSV.

remarks.para: This property specifies what character is used to delimit values within the CSV. The default value delimiter is a double quote ("). If set to , values will never be delimited. Should they require delimiting in order to be valid CSV, an exception will be thrown instead.
If is , delimiters will only be written where necessary. Note that cannot be if is .

member.name: P:KBCsv.CsvWriter.NewLine
member.summary: Gets or sets the used to separate lines within the CSV.
member.remarks: By default, this property is set to .

member.summary: Writes a record to this CsvWriter.

The offset into from which the first record will be obtained.
The number of records to write.

member.name: M:KBCsv.CsvWriter.WriteCharToBuffer(System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Char,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Writes a character to the buffer being used to construct a value.

remarks.para: By default, this method will ensure is if is , , or an end of line character. If is , it will repeat it so that it is escaped in the CSV value.

Subclasses can override this behavior if necessary, but should take care to ensure that the resultant value in is valid for the scenario being addressed. must be set to if the value needs to be delimited prior to writing it to the underlying .

member.param: The buffer containing the value being constructed.
The character to append.
if the value should be delimited.

member.name: T:KBCsv.DataRecord
member.summary: Represents a data record in a CSV file.

remarks.para: A DataRecord represents a CSV record that is not the header record. Values in the data record can be accessed by their index. A data record can have an associated (exposed via ), in which case values in the data record may also be accessed via a column name.

member.name: M:KBCsv.DataRecord.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the DataRecord class.
member.remarks: The resultant data record will have no values, but is not read-only.

member.name: M:KBCsv.DataRecord.#ctor(KBCsv.HeaderRecord)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the DataRecord class.
member.remarks: The resultant data record will have no values, but is not read-only. It will use the specified (which will therefore be returned from ).
member.param: An optional associated with this DataRecord.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the DataRecord class.
member.remarks: The resultant data record will the specified values, and is not read-only. It will use the specified (which will therefore be returned from ).
member.param: An optional associated with this DataRecord.
The values comprising this DataRecord.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the DataRecord class.
member.remarks: The resultant data record will have the specified values, and may or may not be read-only. It will use the specified (which will therefore be returned from ).
member.param: An optional associated with this DataRecord.
to mark this DataRecord as read-only.

member.summary: Gets the in use by this data record.
member.remarks: In order to get or set values in a data record via their column name, a header record must be provided. This property gets the that this data record uses to resolve column indexes given a column name.

member.returns: The value in the specified column.

member.summary: Gets a value in this data record given the column name, or if the specified column does not exist, or if there is no value in this data record at the column's index.
member.param: The name of the column.
member.returns: The value in the specified column, or if the column does not exist, or if there is no value in this data record at the column's index.

member.summary: Determines whether this data record is equal to another.
member.remarks: Data records are considered equal if their s are equal (or both absent), and if their values are equal.
member.param: The other data record.
member.returns: if the data records are equal, otherwise .

member.name: T:KBCsv.HeaderRecord
member.summary: Represents the header record of a CSV file.

remarks.para: A HeaderRecord is a specialized whose values are the names of columns in the CSV. It permits the index of each column to be obtained given its name (see and ).

Note that there is a cost to maintaining the indexes of columns by their name. If possible, favor passing in all column names during construction. Otherwise, favor using only, avoiding , and wherever possible.

member.name: M:KBCsv.HeaderRecord.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the HeaderRecord class.
member.remarks: The resultant header record will have no values, but is not read-only.

member.name: M:KBCsv.HeaderRecord.#ctor(System.String[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the HeaderRecord class with the specified column names.
member.remarks: The resultant header record will have the specified column names as values and is not read-only.
member.param: The names of the columns in the header record.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the HeaderRecord class.
member.param: The names of the columns in the header record.
if the header record is read-only, otherwise .

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the HeaderRecord class with the specified column names.
member.remarks: The resultant header record will have the specified column names as values and is not read-only.
member.param: The names of the columns in the header record.

member.name: T:KBCsv.RecordBase
member.summary: A base class for CSV records.

remarks.para: A record consists of zero or more non- values, which are accessible via their index. returns the number of values in the record. A record may be read-only, as indicated by the property. Read-only records will throw an exception if any attempt is made to modify the record, such as by calling or .

member.name: M:KBCsv.RecordBase.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})

member.returns: The value at the specified index.

member.name: M:KBCsv.RecordBase.Equals(KBCsv.RecordBase)
member.summary: Determines whether this record is equal to another.
member.remarks: Records are considered equal if they have the same number of values, and every corresponding value is equal.
member.param: The other record.
member.returns: if the records are equal, otherwise .
